title: 105_hr4046
content: Restrictions on transfers or discharges of nursing facility residents in case of voluntary withdrawal from Medicaid program. Restrictions on transfers or discharges of nursing facility residents in case of voluntary withdrawal from Medicaid program. Amendment to Section 1919(c)(2) of the Social Security Act regarding continuing rights for nursing facilities voluntarily withdrawing from participation in a State plan. Residents cannot be transferred or discharged based solely on the facility's withdrawal. Residents in a nursing facility cannot be transferred or discharged solely due to the facility's withdrawal from the Medicaid program. The facility must continue to follow the provisions of the section until residents are discharged. New residents must be informed orally and in writing about the implications of the withdrawal. The individual must sign a written acknowledgment of receipt of information separate from other documents. Nursing facilities must provide advance notice before terminating participation agreements. New residents must be informed that the facility is not participating in the Medicaid program. The facility may transfer or discharge a resident unable to pay charges, even if eligible for medical assistance. Continuation of payments and oversight authority are maintained for residents in this situation. The facility's voluntary withdrawal from participation under the State plan allows for receiving payments for nursing facility services, maintaining compliance with requirements, and applying survey and enforcement authority. The provisions also apply to significant reductions in participation. The provisions apply to significant voluntary reductions in participation for residents entitled to medical assistance for nursing facility services. New residents are not affected by these provisions. The provisions do not apply to new residents entering a facility after the withdrawal date. The effective date of the amendment applies to voluntary withdrawals or reductions in participation after the enactment of the Act. A report on the impact of the changes will be submitted to Congress within 5 years, analyzing the effects on nursing facilities, residents, and Medicaid beneficiaries. The amendment allows for voluntary withdrawals or reductions in Medicaid participation in nursing facilities, with a report on the impact to be submitted to Congress within 5 years. Recommendations for legislative changes may be made by the Secretary based on the analysis of the effects.
